historicalFigures.name: Jomo Kenyatta
historicalFigures.background: Jomo Kenyatta was an anti-colonial activist and politician who governed Kenya as its Prime Minister and then as its first President. He is considered the founding father of the Kenyan nation.
keyDecisions: Leading the Kenya African National Union (KANU).
challenges: The Mau Mau Uprising (accused of managing it).
historicalFigures.legacy: Kenyatta is the colossus of Kenyan history. His face is on the currency. His legacy is mixed due to accusations of tribal favoritism.
quotes: Our children may learn about the heroes of the past. Our task is to make ourselves the architects of the future.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Jomo Kenyatta International Airport is named after him. He is the symbol of the state.

historicalFigures.name: Wangari Maathai
historicalFigures.background: Wangari Maathai was a social, environmental, and political activist. She founded the Green Belt Movement, which focused on planting trees, environmental conservation, and women's rights.
keyDecisions: Protesting against the construction of a skyscraper in Uhuru Park.
achievements: Nobel Peace Prize (2004) - first African woman.
challenges: Political persecution by the Moi regime.
historicalFigures.legacy: Maathai is a global icon. She showed the link between environment, democracy, and peace.
quotes: It's the little things citizens do. That's what will make the difference. My little thing is planting trees.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a role model for women and environmentalists worldwide.

historicalFigures.name: Dedan Kimathi
historicalFigures.background: Dedan Kimathi was the senior military and spiritual leader of the Mau Mau Uprising. He led the armed struggle against British colonial rule from the forests of the Aberdares.
keyDecisions: Forming the Kenya Land and Freedom Army (Mau Mau).
Inspiring his fighters with discipline and spirituality.
achievements: Field Marshal of the Mau Mau.
Kept the British army at bay for years.
historicalFigures.legacy: Kimathi is the ultimate hero of the resistance. His statue stands in Nairobi where he was executed.
quotes: I would rather die on my feet than live on my knees.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a symbol of sacrifice. The Kimathi University is named after him.
modernInterpretations: His role was suppressed by post-independence governments for decades.

historicalFigures.name: Daniel arap Moi
historicalFigures.background: Daniel arap Moi was the second President of Kenya, ruling from 1978 to 2002. His regime was known as 'Nyayo' (Footsteps) and was characterized by stability but also authoritarianism.
keyDecisions: Making Kenya a one-party state (de jure).
Implementing the Nyayo philosophy (Peace, Love, and Unity).
achievements: Kept Kenya stable in a turbulent region.
historicalFigures.legacy: Moi is the 'Professor of Politics'. He survived every crisis. His legacy is one of survival and repression.
quotes: Siasa mbaya, maisha mbaya (Bad politics, bad life).
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His 'Fimbo ya Nyayo' (ivory baton) is iconic. He shaped a generation.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a dictator by many.
Respected by some for maintaining peace.

historicalFigures.name: Tom Mboya
historicalFigures.background: Tom Mboya was a brilliant trade unionist and politician. He was a key figure in the independence movement and the architect of the 'Airlifts' that sent Kenyan students (like Obama's father) to the US.
keyDecisions: Serving as Minister of Economic Planning.
historicalFigures.legacy: Mboya is the 'President we never had'. His assassination sparked riots and deepened tribal divisions.
quotes: These are the days of the African giant waking up.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a symbol of what could have been. A statue of him stands in Nairobi.
modernInterpretations: His death is a national trauma.

historicalFigures.name: Mekatilili wa Menza
historicalFigures.background: Mekatilili wa Menza was a Giriama woman leader who led the resistance against the British colonial administration in 1913-1914. She opposed forced labor and taxation.
keyDecisions: Administering oaths to unite the people.
historicalFigures.legacy: Mekatilili is a heroine of the coast. She proved that women could lead wars.
quotes: We will not pay the tax.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: The Mekatilili wa Menza festival is held annually. She is a symbol of female power.

historicalFigures.name: Eliud Kipchoge
historicalFigures.background: Eliud Kipchoge is a long-distance runner widely considered the greatest marathon runner of all time. He is the first human to run a marathon in under two hours (INEOS 1:59 Challenge).
keyDecisions: Living a simple life despite wealth.
challenges: Physical limits of the human body.
historicalFigures.legacy: Kipchoge redefined human limits. His philosophy 'No Human is Limited' is global.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a global sports icon. A philosopher-runner.
modernInterpretations: His discipline is a model for success.

historicalFigures.name: Lupita Nyong'o
historicalFigures.background: Lupita Nyong'o is an Academy Award-winning actress. She is the first Kenyan and Mexican actress to win an Oscar. She is known for her roles in '12 Years a Slave' and 'Black Panther'.
historicalFigures.legacy: Lupita is the pride of Kenya. She shattered beauty standards and opened doors for Africans in Hollywood.
quotes: No matter where you're from, your dreams are valid.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Her Oscar speech is legendary. She is a role model for black girls everywhere.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a talent and beauty icon.
Her success is a source of national joy.

historicalFigures.name: Ngugi wa Thiong'o
historicalFigures.background: Ngugi wa Thiong'o is a novelist, playwright, and theorist. He is one of Africa's most important writers, known for writing in Gikuyu to decolonize the mind.
keyDecisions: Writing 'Ngaahika Ndeenda' (I Will Marry When I Want).
historicalFigures.legacy: Ngugi is the intellectual conscience of Kenya. His theory of language is globally influential.
quotes: Language is a carrier of culture.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He changed how African literature is viewed.
modernInterpretations: His political views are sometimes debated.

historicalFigures.name: Mwai Kibaki
historicalFigures.background: Mwai Kibaki was the third President of Kenya. He is credited with reviving the Kenyan economy and introducing free primary education, but his presidency was marred by the 2007 post-election violence.
keyDecisions: Leading the NARC coalition to defeat KANU.
Swearing himself in at night in 2007.
historicalFigures.legacy: Kibaki is the economist-president. He rebuilt the country's infrastructure but failed to unite it politically.
quotes: Leadership is a privilege to better the lives of others.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is respected for his competence but criticized for the 2007 chaos.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as the best president for the economy.

historicalFigures.name: Tegla Loroupe
historicalFigures.background: Tegla Loroupe is a long-distance runner and peace activist. She was the first African woman to hold the marathon world record and organizes Peace Races to end cattle rustling.
keyDecisions: Founding the Tegla Loroupe Peace Foundation.
historicalFigures.legacy: Tegla is a champion for peace. She uses sport to change the world.
quotes: Peace is not just the absence of war.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Her Peace Races have reduced violence in Northern Kenya.

historicalFigures.name: Richard Leakey
historicalFigures.background: Richard Leakey was a paleoanthropologist and conservationist. He discovered the 'Turkana Boy' and led the Kenya Wildlife Service, famously burning ivory to stop poaching.
keyDecisions: Searching for fossils in Lake Turkana.
achievements: Built the National Museums of Kenya.
historicalFigures.legacy: Leakey is a giant of science and conservation. He put Kenya on the map as the cradle of mankind.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: The ivory burn is a historic moment. He is a controversial but effective leader.
modernInterpretations: Revered for his toughness and vision.
His management style was often criticized.

historicalFigures.name: Oginga Odinga
historicalFigures.background: Jaramogi Oginga Odinga was a prominent independence leader and the first Vice President of Kenya. He became the leader of the opposition and the father of Raila Odinga.
keyDecisions: Refusing the presidency until Kenyatta was released.
historicalFigures.legacy: Jaramogi is the conscience of the left. His phrase 'Not Yet Uhuru' defines the struggle for true freedom.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His family is a political dynasty. He represents the Luo community's aspirations.

historicalFigures.name: Harry Thuku
historicalFigures.background: Harry Thuku was a pioneer of African nationalism in Kenya. He founded the Young Kikuyu Association and led protests against the colonial government in the 1920s.
keyDecisions: Organizing protests against the kipande system.
Becoming a moderate farmer later in life.
challenges: Split with the more radical Mau Mau.
historicalFigures.legacy: Thuku is the grandfather of Kenyan nationalism. His early work was crucial.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Harry Thuku Road is a major street in Nairobi.
modernInterpretations: His later conservatism is often overlooked.

historicalFigures.name: Pio Gama Pinto
historicalFigures.background: Pio Gama Pinto was a Kenyan journalist and socialist politician of Goan descent. He was a key strategist for the Mau Mau and the first Kenyan politician to be assassinated after independence.
keyDecisions: Supplying arms to the Mau Mau.
Founding the Kenya African National Union (KANU) newspaper.
challenges: Being an Asian in an African movement.
historicalFigures.legacy: Pinto is the unsung hero. His assassination marked the end of innocence for independent Kenya.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a hero to the left.
modernInterpretations: His death is seen as the start of political violence.

historicalFigures.name: Kipchoge Keino
historicalFigures.background: Kipchoge Keino is a retired track and field athlete and the father of Kenyan running. His victory in the 1968 Olympics despite a gallbladder infection is legendary.
keyDecisions: Running to the stadium to make his race in 1968.
Founding the Kip Keino High Performance Training Centre.
historicalFigures.legacy: Keino started the Kenyan running dynasty. He is a national treasure.
quotes: To win is not important. To be successful is not even important. How to plan and prepare is crucial.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He put Kenya on the sporting map. The Kip Keino Classic is named after him.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a legend and humanitarian.

historicalFigures.name: Raila Odinga
historicalFigures.background: Raila Odinga is a veteran opposition leader and former Prime Minister. He is the son of Jaramogi Oginga Odinga and has been a central figure in Kenyan politics for decades.
historicalFigures.legacy: Raila is the 'People's President'. He is loved and loathed in equal measure.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He commands a fanatical following. 'Baba' is a household name.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a democrat by supporters.
Viewed as a disruptor by opponents.

historicalFigures.name: Uhuru Kenyatta
historicalFigures.background: Uhuru Kenyatta was the fourth President of Kenya and the son of Jomo Kenyatta. He was indicted by the ICC for crimes against humanity but the charges were dropped.
challenges: Fallout with his deputy William Ruto.
historicalFigures.legacy: Uhuru is the infrastructure president. His legacy is defined by roads and railways, but also debt.
modernInterpretations: Criticized for the economy and debt.
